case_name: Civil Appeal Nos. 2415 of 1972 and 128 to 132 of 1973

facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 2415 of 1972 and 128 to 132 of 1973 are appeals by special leave from judgments and order dated 14th February 1972 of Madras High Court in WPs Nos. 3062/71 and 3069-3073/71.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 2415 of 1972 and 128 to 132 of 1973. Appeals by Special Leave from the Judgments and Order dated the 14th February, 1972 of the Madras High Court in WPs. Nos. 3062/71 and 3069-3073 of 1971.

facts.text: Government of Tamil Nadu imposed enhancement of motor vehicles tax on omnibuses by G.O. No. 2044-Home dated 20-9-1971 from Rs. 30 per seat per quarter to Rs. 100 per seat per quarter.

anchor.surface_text: In the Civil Appeals, the questions for consideration are whether the enhancement of motor vehicles tax on omnibuses imposed by G.O. No. 2044-Home dated 20-9- 1971 by the Government of Tamil Nadu from Rs. 30 per seat per quarter to Rs. 100/- per seat per quarter is constitutionally valid

facts.text: Petitioner is owner of omnibus with capacity to accommodate 54 passengers.

anchor.surface_text: We take up for consideration Writ Petition No. 253 of 1973 and the judgment therein will dispose of the Civil Appeals and the Writ Petitions. The petitioner is the owner of an omnibus which has a capacity to accommodate 54 passengers.

facts.text: Petitioner obtained permit on 16-5-1968 to operate omnibus as contract carriage.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained a permit on 16-5-1968 to operate it as a contract carriage and was paying tax at the rate of Rs. 30/- per seat per quarter under the Madras Motor Vehicles Taxation Act 3 of 1931

facts.text: Petitioner was paying tax at Rs. 30 per seat per quarter under Madras Motor Vehicles Taxation Act 1931.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained a permit on 16-5-1968 to operate it as a contract carriage and was paying tax at the rate of Rs. 30/- per seat per quarter under the Madras Motor Vehicles Taxation Act 3 of 1931  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Madras Motor Vehicles Taxation Act 1931 was passed to abolish levy of tolls in Presidency of Madras and levy of taxes on motor vehicles by local bodies.

anchor.surface_text: This Act was passed with a view to abolish levy of tolls in the Presidency of Madras and the, levy of taxes on motor vehicles by local bodies. The rate of tax which originally stood at Rs. 10/- per seat per quarter

facts.text: Original rate of tax was Rs. 10 per seat per quarter, increased to Rs. 30 per seat per quarter.

anchor.surface_text: The rate of tax which originally stood at Rs. 10/- per seat per quarter was increased to Rs. 30/- per seat per quarter when the systems of issuing permits for omnibuses by the regional transport authorities came into vogue.

facts.text: Government of Tamil Nadu by G.O.M.S. 923-Home dated 19-4-1969 increased tax on omnibuses from Rs. 30 to Rs. 50 per seat per quarter w.e.f. 1-7-1969.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Tamil Nadu by G.O.M.S. 923-Home dated 19-4- 1969 increased the rate of tax with respect to omnibuses from Rs. 30/- to Rs. 50/- per seat per quarter with effect from 1-7-1969.

facts.text: Owners questioned validity of G.O.M.S. 923 in Writ Petition No. 1412 of 1969 etc.

anchor.surface_text: The owners of omnibuses questioned the validity of the notification in Writ Petition No. 1412 of 1969, etc. During the pendency of those writ petitions, the government increased the rate of tax

facts.text: Government increased tax from Rs. 50 to Rs. 100 per seat per quarter w.e.f. 1-9-1970 by G.O.M.S. 434-Home dated 27-2-1970.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of those writ petitions, the government increased the rate of tax from Rs. SO - to Rs. 100/- per seat per quarter with effect from 1-9-1970 by G.O.M.S. 434- Home dated 27-2-1970.

facts.text: Madras High Court by common judgment dated 29-1-1971 allowed writ petitions and quashed the notifications G.O.M.S. 923 and 434, restoring tax to Rs. 30 per seat per quarter.

anchor.surface_text: By a common judgment dated 29-1-1971, the High Court allowed the writ petitions and quashed the aforesaid notifications holding that the notifications were a device to eliminate the operation of contract carriages and that the notifications were not made in the exercise of the power of taxation.

facts.text: Government of Tamil Nadu issued G.O.M.S. 2544 Home dated 20-1-1971 enhancing tax from Rs. 30 to Rs. 100 per seat per quarter w.e.f. 1-7-1971.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Government of Tamil Nadu issued G.O.M.S. 2544 Home dated 20-1-1971 enhancing the tax from Rs. 30/- to Rs. 100/per seat per quarter with effect from 1-7-1971. It is this G.O. which the petitioner challenges in the writ petition.

facts.text: Petitioners claim the notification is not a measure of taxation but a device to eliminate competition of omnibuses with stage carriages.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the petitioner submitted, firstly, that the notification was not a measure of taxation but a device to eliminate the competition of omnibuses with stage carriages run by Government and, therefore, the tax is bad.

facts.text: Tax imposed under Section 4 of Madras Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1931.

anchor.surface_text: The tax was imposed by the Government in the exercise of its power under s. 4 of the Madras Motor Vehicles Taxation Act, 1931. That section provides 4 1  The State Government may, by notification in the official gazette,

facts.text: Court holds that motive for imposing tax is immaterial if government had power to impose it.

anchor.surface_text: As the state legislature was competent to pass the Act and as the Government is authorised under S. 4 to levy the tax, the question of the motive with which the tax was imposed is immaterial.

facts.text: Government incurred expenditure of Rs. 19.51 crores in 1970-71 on maintenance and construction of roads, receipts from vehicle tax Rs. 16.38 crores.

anchor.surface_text: In the counter-affidavit filed on behalf of the State, the averment is that Government has incurred an expenditure of Rs. 19.51 crores in the year 1970-71 on the maintenance and construction of roads while the receipts from out of vehicle tax is only Rs. 16.38 crores.

facts.text: Court finds the tax is compensatory in character and does not restrict freedom under Article 301.

anchor.surface_text: If the tax is compensatory or regulatory, it cannot operate as a restriction on the freedom of trade or commerce. The question for consideration then is, whether the tax here, is a compensatory tax.

facts.text: Higher tax on contract carriages than stage carriages because contract carriages can run more miles, cause more wear and tear.

anchor.surface_text: Hence the contract carriages can run a larger number of miles than stage carriages and therefore the wear and tear of the road caused would be greater and in the case of roads which are not fit for such operation,

facts.text: Stage carriages limited to 250 miles per day by rule.

anchor.surface_text: The stage carriages have to operate only on fixed time schedules and on fixed routes and the number of miles they can negotiate is limited by the rule to 250 miles.

facts.text: Court holds classification between contract and stage carriages for tax rates is reasonable and not violative of Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: Since the petitioners and the appellants have not discharged the burden of proving that the classification is unreasonable, we hold that the levy of an enhanced rate of vehicle tax on contract carriages was not hit by Article 14.

facts.text: Writ petitions and appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the writ petitions and appeals without any order as to costs.

facts.text: Tax on stage carriages is Rs. 65/- per seat per quarter plus surcharge.

anchor.surface_text: In the counter-affidavit it is also stated that the rate of tax payable on stage carriage is Rs. 651- per seat per quarter and a surcharge of 10 paise per rupee on the fare collected,

facts.text: Contract carriage defined in Section 2(3) of Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 3  of the Motor Vehicles Act, 19,39, defines contract carriage as follows contract carriage means a motor vehicle which carries a passenger or passengers for hire or reward under a contract expressed or implied

facts.text: Stage carriage defined in Section 2(29) of Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: Stage carriage has been defined in S. 2 29  of that Act as under stage carriage means a motor vehicle carrying or adapted to carry more than six persons excluding the driver which carries passengers for hire or reward

offends Article 14 of the Constitution. holdings.text: As the state legislature was competent to pass the Act and as the Government is authorised under S. 4 to levy the tax, the question of the motive with which the tax was imposed is immaterial.

anchor.surface_text: As the state legislature was competent to pass the Act and as the Government is authorised under S. 4 to levy the tax, the question of the motive with which the tax was imposed is immaterial. To put it differently,

holdings.reasoning_summary: State legislature competent to enact Act; executive authorised by s.4 to impose tax by notification; presence of power renders motive irrelevant even if aimed at eliminating competition.

holdings.text: we think the tax imposed by the notification is compensatory in character and would not, therefore, restrict the freedom of trade and commerce according to the decision in Automobile Case supra.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to pursue the matter further, as we think the tax imposed by the notification is compensatory in character and would not, therefore, restrict the freedom of trade and commerce according to the decision in Automobile Case supra . In the Civil Appeals,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax for road use where expenditure on roads exceeds receipts; rough approximation sufficient; follows Automobile case clarifying compensatory taxes outside Art 301 restrictions.

holdings.text: we do not think that any material has been placed before us to hold that the tax is confiscatory and operates as an unreasonable restriction upon the appellants right to carry on the trade. We have already held that the tax is compensatory in character.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first contention is concerned, we do not think that any material has been placed before us to hold that the tax is confiscatory and operates as an unreasonable restriction upon the appellants right to carry on the trade. We have already held that the tax is compensatory in character.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of confiscation; compensatory nature means commensurate with services received; part of business costs, no unreasonable restriction on Art 19(1)(g).

holdings.text: Since the petitioners and the appellants have not discharged the burden of proving that the classification is unreasonable, we hold that the levy of an enhanced rate of vehicle tax on contract carriages was not hit by Article 14.
